docs.lead_paragraph: One hardly wants to disparage the orchestral, chamber and recital components of Lincoln Center's Great Performers schedule, but over the last 10 years it has been the vocal component of the series that has yielded the most consistently memorable performances, or in more immediate terms, the ones that linger in a listener's ears and thoughts long after the final bow. The recital that Christine Schafer gave at Alice Tully Hall on Sunday afternoon had that effect for a number of reasons, some to do with her program -- songs by Wolf and Messiaen -- and some to do with the velvety, warm-hued sound that this soprano and her pianist, Eric Schneider, brought to the music. It was, for the most part, a program in which both text and music used gentle textures to evoke powerful emotions, spiritual and mundane.

headline.main: Text and Music Evoking Emotions, Spiritual and Mundane

docs.snippet: One hardly wants to disparage the orchestral, chamber and recital components of Lincoln Center's Great Performers schedule, but over the last 10 years it has been the vocal component of the series that has yielded the most consistently memorable...

docs.lead_paragraph: The resolution seemed innocuous enough. A bipartisan group of members of Congress, hoping to show good will to Arab-Americans and the nearly five million Muslims in the United States, sponsored a resolution condemning ''anti-Muslim intolerance and discrimination.''

headline.main: Measure of Good Will Toward Muslims Backfires in House

docs.lead_paragraph: Germany's Roman Catholic bishops bowed today to insistent demands from Pope John Paul II that they stop issuing certificates that open the way for women to have abortions. Under German law, a woman may have a legal abortion during the first 12 weeks of pregnancy provided that she can present proof that she has first attended a counseling center, many of which are run by the Roman Catholic Church.

headline.main: German Bishops to Halt Abortion Certificates

docs.lead_paragraph: Gov. George W. Bush of Texas today made clear his strong opposition to most abortions and implied that while he would not, if elected president, make that viewpoint the principal consideration in appointing Supreme Court justices, he might not dismiss it, either. ''I want to know how a judge feels about a lot of issues,'' Mr. Bush said in a live hourlong interview with a television journalist, Tim Russert, on the NBC News program ''Meet the Press.''

headline.main: Bush Explains His Opposition to Abortion

docs.snippet: Gov. George W. Bush of Texas today made clear his strong opposition to most abortions and implied that while he would not, if elected president, make that viewpoint the principal consideration in appointing Supreme Court justices, he might not...

docs.lead_paragraph: It was a long wait, particularly long because the bathrooms were placed off limits for security reasons, long enough even for the Champagne and the caviar canapes to run out, but when President Clinton arrived he quickly wowed a glittering audience with visions of a juster world. The setting was New York University's Florentine retreat, Villa La Pietra, complete with Donatellos. So it was perhaps inevitable that the president should turn to the fruitful ferment of the Renaissance to illustrate his conviction that a similar era of enriching inventiveness is now being driven by the Internet and a global economy.

headline.main: Reporter's Notebook; Clinton, a Renaissance Guy, Paints the Globe Bright
